rest.sentence: Perovskite solar cells  are the most promising candidate for next-generation photovoltaics
The carrier dynamics behavior in perovskite is closely related to the performance of the solar cell
Particularly, manipulating the hot carriers has the potential to achieve ultrahigh-efficiency solar cells beyond the conventional Shockley-Queisser efficiency limit
Therefore, it is crucial to study and understand the carrier transport process in perovskite
However, the carrier dynamics behavior in the femtosecond time scale is difficult to be detected
Nowadays, femtosecond transient absorption techniques address this challenge effectively

We summarize the monitoring of hot carriers cooling, trapping of defect states, and charge transfer process after photoexcitation of PSCs by transient absorption and analyze the effective utilization of carriers in these processes
Finally, an outlook that will encounter in its future development is provided.
Given the global concerns surrounding climate change and energy issues, the employment of solar energy, as a pure and sustainable source of power, is gaining significant momentum
Thus far, photovoltaics has demonstrated the most promising technology for converting sunlight into electricity
In recent times, perovskites have garnered substantial attention for their numerous advantages, not only in the domain of solar cells but also in other application fields.
Perovskite represent a class of semiconductor materials boasting a band gap that falls within the range of 1.24 eV to 3.55 eV , as well as a relatively low exciton binding energy

Further, these materials exhibit an impressive carrier diffusion length  of 1 micrometer, and high light absorption coefficient  in the visible region, which can be manipulated via component regulation
These benefits facilitate wide-ranging applications in the realms of solar cells , light emitting diodes , semiconductor lasers  and photodetectors

Notably, within the realm of photovoltaics, PSCs have attained a power conversion efficacy of 25.7% , which offers unique advantages in terms of their uncomplicated preparation process and economical cost, rendering them the most encouraging option for next-generation photovoltaic applications

Currently, researchers are primarily focused on developing high-quality, low-defect perovskite films, as the efficiency of large-area PSCs remains inadequate in comparison to other industrial photovoltaic devices

This is attributed to the significant presence of vacancy defects on the surface of perovskite films and the consequential non-radiative recombination of carriers at the device interface, resulting in reduced efficiency

To overcome these challenges, researchers have implemented diverse approaches such as interfacial modification , surface post-treatment to reduce interfacial non-radiative recombination , and process optimization to eliminate surface defect states

The processes governing the motion of photogenerated carriers in perovskite, under ultrashort pulse excitation, occur not in a linear sequence, but rather overlap in time to form a continuous chain of processes spanning the entire range from femtosecond  to microsecond timescales

Upon absorption of photons by perovskite, excitons or carriers in the femtosecond to picosecond  range are generated, which are subsequently transported via diffusion or drift in the perovskite absorption layer on the nanosecond  timescale
Under conditions of high flux and excitation well above the band gap, hot carriers with longer lifetimes ranging from a few hundred fs to tens of ps can be observed
The extraction of the charge transfer layer, typically taking a few microseconds, is necessary to collect the extracted carriers
During these process, carrier capture and recombination typically occurs on timescales ranging from hundreds of ps to a few tens of ns ,
As can be observed, a quick method of detection is urgently needed for the process of carrier motion quickly following perovskite photoexcitation
The rapid hot carrier cooling , non-radiative processes  within the perovskite and its interface, and charge transfer often take place within the fs to ps timeframe
Utilizing femtosecond pumping transient absorption  is an efficacious method for comprehending the carrier dynamics of perovskite films following optical excitation
Investigating and comprehending the carrier dynamics within perovskites are intricately tied to the performance of PSCs
Specifically, controlling the behavior of hot carriers holds the potential for achieving ultrahigh-efficiency solar cells that surpass the conventional Shockley-Queisser  efficiency limit .

Investigating the cooling of hot carriers , auger recombination of charge carriers , the capture of defect states , and the transfer of interfacial charges  in perovskite absorber layers post photoexcitation are of significant importance
Consequently, numerous studies have delved into these processes through femtosecond TA spectroscopy ,

Based on our research experiences in the two areas of ultrafast transient absorption and PSCs , this review is presented to highlight the monitoring of photogenerated carrier dynamics processes in PSCs by TA
During the operation of the perovskite solar cell, a multitude of processes take place, such as hot carrier cooling, defect capture, interfacial charge transfer, and carrier recombination
In these processes, achieving rapid carrier extraction and transfer has been the main focus of research

In addition to maximizing the lifetime of hot carriers and investigating materials that can efficiently extract hot carriers, reducing internal and interfacial defects in materials to minimize non-radiative carrier recombination is also a prominent research objective

Additionally, designing and preparing appropriate charge extraction layers to extract charge as much as possible before electron-hole radiative recombination occurs is essential for achieving optimal carrier utilization efficiency

The present review is logically divided into five sections:  introduction,  transient absorption technique,  monitoring ultra-short hot carrier lifetimes,  analyzing defect states,  monitoring charge transfer and  conclusion and outlook.
